intro: Sida pseudocordifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf sida, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant typically grows as an annual herb with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are elliptic to ovate in shape. Its small, white flowers are arranged in clusters and bloom during the warm season. The plant is characterized by its mucilaginous seeds, which can be used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive.
